critique:
This document establishes a naval defensive sea area and airspace reservation around Kaneohe Bay in Hawaii. It restricts access to these areas to only public vessels and aircraft of the United States, unless authorized by the Secretary of the Navy. The order is for national defense purposes and is enforceable by the Secretary of the Navy with the cooperation of local law enforcement. Violations are subject to penalties under existing laws. The document itself doesn't directly address ideological issues, immigration, or social inclusion. It expands executive power to control access to these areas for national security. It also centralizes control at the federal level. It prioritizes national security over individual liberties within the designated area. It does not directly regulate the economy. Therefore, the initial scores are as follows:

Ideological Tilt: 0 (Centrist/Moderate)
Immigration Approach: 0 (Balanced/Selective)
Executive Power: 3 (Moderately Expands Executive Authority)
Federalism: 3 (Moderately Strong Federal Control)
National Security vs. Civil Liberties: 3 (Moderately Heavy National Security Focus)
Economic Regulation: 0 (Moderate Regulation)
Social Inclusion: 0 (Neutral)

Upon further reflection, the expansion of executive power and federal control are more pronounced given the restrictions imposed and the enforcement mechanism. The prioritization of national security also seems stronger in this context. Therefore, the revised scores are as follows:
